blocks.text: It is now possible to give the proof of this rule.
Let us deal with a portion of the full area to be measured, such as ABCD in Fig. 35. Let the area AB = \(c\). Let us repeat the curve DBC be \(y = f(x)\) so that DBC is a portion of some surface.
We can assume that the origin is at F, and therefore the abscissae of D, B, C and A are \(x_0, x_1, x_2\) and \(x_3\) respectively.
Hence  \(A = y_1 = (A + B + C + D) = A - B + C \Rightarrow A = \frac{ \int_{x_0}^{x_1}(f(x) + f(x_1))dx}{2}\)

blocks.latex: \text{Now the area ABCD = } \int_{x_0}^{x_1} y dx = \int_{x_0}^{x_1} f(x) dx
blocks.description: This equation represents the area under the curve from \(x_0\) to \(x_1\).
